issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.summary: VIRTIO_DISK setting should be 0 for Precise, since with 1 libvirtd and NC may lock up

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
I've created three volumes and started three instances. After all instances become available and running I ran attach-volume for each instance (one volume per instance). I did this in HA set up with SAN (Equallogic) adapter.

This is long from an NC:
{code}
[Tue Jun 12 16:41:30 2012][030733][EUCAINFO  ] [i-909A4370] doAttachVolume: invoked (vol=vol-31703CDC remote=192.168.7.189,iqn.2001-05.com.equallogic:0-8a0906-2fd1dd504-2100
000569c4fd79-vol-31703cdc,MQPhnaOXwN8+PU/BWzLvd0f+do1lGWn1ytjvMyxGtt8jG1XrEVnM9qoYR2fHXyRp3ShUm0TF5iL3v84fc+RSjRUyg0GznpWhrIVPygC6Pj7V0HQejsfTVVniEgQLpeD53jT7QoPNjtVFzuhbFwz
22Uir/AXjfyEjXaY5jQdsK5FP/5/L4gcbrFdoUvxFbW+Di+40o3wh1PbmpzeUa1An4nAWVuLhdOJaG6AYsyW/IikiLDIJ3pdadCWKN7Gfy/y/jqtvTjhohvihDPKoF+bW8JF5KZvRfW79P9YYBpiO+EzOitpWokwVvBrbAu0htks0
0OQpLn3XQfcbpKtlsr8OVA== local=/dev/sdb1)
[Tue Jun 12 16:41:30 2012][030733][EUCAINFO  ] connect_iscsi_target invoked (dev_string=192.168.7.189,iqn.2001-05.com.equallogic:0-8a0906-2fd1dd504-2100000569c4fd79-vol-3170
3cdc,MQPhnaOXwN8+PU/BWzLvd0f+do1lGWn1ytjvMyxGtt8jG1XrEVnM9qoYR2fHXyRp3ShUm0TF5iL3v84fc+RSjRUyg0GznpWhrIVPygC6Pj7V0HQejsfTVVniEgQLpeD53jT7QoPNjtVFzuhbFwz22Uir/AXjfyEjXaY5jQds
K5FP/5/L4gcbrFdoUvxFbW+Di+40o3wh1PbmpzeUa1An4nAWVuLhdOJaG6AYsyW/IikiLDIJ3pdadCWKN7Gfy/y/jqtvTjhohvihDPKoF+bW8JF5KZvRfW79P9YYBpiO+EzOitpWokwVvBrbAu0htks00OQpLn3XQfcbpKtlsr8OVA==)
[Tue Jun 12 16:41:30 2012][022355][EUCADEBUG ] connect_iscsi_target(): running command: //usr/lib/eucalyptus/euca_rootwrap //usr/share/eucalyptus/connect_iscsitarget.pl /,192.168.7.189,iqn.2001-05.com.equallogic:0-8a0906-2fd1dd504-2100000569c4fd79-vol-31703cdc,
[Tue Jun 12 16:41:32 2012][030733][EUCADEBUG ] [i-506E3FC8] get_instance_stats: blkdevs=sda3,sda2,sda1,sda, blkMB=202 netdevs=vnet0 netMB=0
[Tue Jun 12 16:41:33 2012][030733][EUCADEBUG ] [i-03FC3F05] get_instance_stats: blkdevs=sda3,sda2,sda1,sda, blkMB=206 netdevs=vnet1 netMB=0
[Tue Jun 12 16:41:33 2012][030733][EUCADEBUG ] [i-B35F3F0A] get_instance_stats: blkdevs=sda3,sda2,sda1,sda, blkMB=238 netdevs=vnet2 netMB=0
[Tue Jun 12 16:41:33 2012][030733][EUCADEBUG ] [i-909A4370] get_instance_stats: blkdevs=sda3,sda2,sda1,sda, blkMB=198 netdevs=vnet3 netMB=0
[Tue Jun 12 16:41:33 2012][022355][EUCAINFO  ] connect_iscsi_target(): attached host device name: /dev/sdd
[Tue Jun 12 16:41:33 2012][030733][EUCADEBUG ] [i-909A4370] attached iSCSI target of host device '/dev/sdd'
[Tue Jun 12 16:41:33 2012][030733][EUCAINFO  ] [i-909A4370] wrote volume XML to /disk1/storage/eucalyptus/instances/work/5TFCRRDT05KKLBHXNGXD2/i-909A4370/vol-31703CDC.xml
{code}

After that the NC waits (possible deadlocks) for a long time. This leads to CC de-registering this node. If CC evenly (round-robin) distributes instances to all NC all NCs could be eventually de-registered.

This is log from the same NC 2 hours later
{code}
[Tue Jun 12 18:42:13 2012][030733][EUCAERROR ] libvirt: Cannot write data: Broken pipe (code=38)
[Tue Jun 12 18:42:13 2012][030733][EUCAWARN  ] [i-506E3FC8] warning: hypervisor failed to find domain, will retry 4 more times

[Tue Jun 12 18:42:13 2012][030733][EUCAERROR ] libvirt: Cannot write data: Broken pipe (code=38)
[Tue Jun 12 18:42:13 2012][030733][EUCAWARN  ] [i-909A4370] warning: hypervisor failed to find domain, will retry 4 more times
[Tue Jun 12 18:42:13 2012][030733][EUCADEBUG ] AttachVolume(): attempting to disconnect iscsi target due to attachment failure
[Tue Jun 12 18:42:13 2012][030733][EUCAINFO  ] disconnect_iscsi_target invoked (dev_string=192.168.7.189,iqn.2001-05.com.equallogic:0-8a0906-2fd1dd504-2100000569c4fd79-vol-3
1703cdc,MQPhnaOXwN8+PU/BWzLvd0f+do1lGWn1ytjvMyxGtt8jG1XrEVnM9qoYR2fHXyRp3ShUm0TF5iL3v84fc+RSjRUyg0GznpWhrIVPygC6Pj7V0HQejsfTVVniEgQLpeD53jT7QoPNjtVFzuhbFwz22Uir/AXjfyEjXaY5j

8OVA==)
[Tue Jun 12 18:42:13 2012][023241][EUCADEBUG ] disconnect_iscsi_target(): running command: //usr/lib/eucalyptus/euca_rootwrap //usr/share/eucalyptus/disconnect_iscsitarget.p

[Tue Jun 12 18:42:13 2012][023241][EUCAINFO  ] vrun(): [//usr/lib/eucalyptus/euca_rootwrap //usr/share/eucalyptus/disconnect_iscsitarget.pl /,192.168.7.189,iqn.2001-05.com.e

fields.summary: Attach volume on Ubuntu 12.04 64-bit makes cluster nonfunctional

comments.body: Just attached the file with the troubleshooting information Dima and I gathered yesterday.
I was not able to reproduce this problem with the image that triggered the issue using CentOS set up. I was able to reproduce it again with different image on the Ubuntu Precise.
Thanks Vasya. I'm regressing a build right now with a potential fix. I'll have something to test with in the morning.

Attaching the NC logs and GDB debug info for the issue encountered once the potential fix was implemented.

The call to virDomainAttachDevice() hung and the NC was able to time it out but the next virDomainXXX() call caused the NC to hang again. This time libvirt was totally hosed but the NC virDomainXXX() call was able to time out 2 minutes later. Although the NC was still running (no longer hung) libvirt has to be restarted since all subsequent call to libvirt APIs will timeout.
Disabling USE_VIRTIO_DISK (set to "0") in eucalyptus.conf for Ubuntu is a good work around for this issue.
EUCA-2338 has been opened to take care of the USE_VIRTIO_DISK flag in eucalyptus.conf for 3.1.0 release on Ubuntu distro.
demoting for 3.1; fix is represented in EUCA-2338
Finally got the debug library installed for libvirt (libvirt0-dbg). This gave me the missing symbols when running gdb. The attached 'bt_with_debug.txt' file contains all the gdb thread info.

Backtrace from NC
{code}
doAttachVolume()
  -> doAttachVolume()
    -> virDomainAttachDevice()
      -> remoteDomainAttachDevice()
        -> call()
          -> callWithFD()
            -> virNetClientProgramCall()
              -> virNetClientSendWithReply()
                -> virNetClientIO()
                  -> virNetClientIOEventLoop()
                    -> poll()
{code}

Ok,

Finally was able to compile and load libvirt 0.9.13. The problem was that their config file got changed a bit and things didn't line up anymore. With the proper config I was able to load up the new libvirtd 

{code}
root@eucahost-51-165:~# /usr/sbin/libvirtd --version
/usr/sbin/libvirtd (libvirt) 0.9.13
root@eucahost-51-165:~# 
{code}

With this new release, I was able to launch an instance and install a volume without getting the NC stuck. Here's the 2 bugs that were fixed in 0.9.13 that I believed related to our problem:

{code}
client rpc: Fix error checking after poll() (Daniel P. Berrange),
client rpc: Send keepalive requests from IO event loop (Jiri Denemark),
{code}

I personally think the later is our problem where they got stuck in an event loop which means that we could potentially have other stuck cases that could be related to this. 

Release 0.9.13-RC2 is experimental for debian and the unstable version is 0.9.12.
This is fixed in libvirt release 0.9.13. This has been tested by starting an instance and attaching a volume to /dev/sdb1. With libvirt release 0.9.8 this would have triggered the NC to lockup.
Re-opened until I can submit a Launchpad case with the distro.
